channel.title: NPR All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Ari Shapiro, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.

item.title: How contrasting neighborhoods in D.C. feel about the National Guard in their city
item.description: Washington, D.C., residents are torn about the National Guard in their city. The majority Democrat city doesn't support Trump. Are liberal upper-income residents honest about the problems of crime?

item.title: A small town teacher ended up with a summer education project without even trying
item.description: A teacher's students became enthusiastic about her summer side hustle. In the end, everybody learned something without even trying.

item.title: Tennis is getting rowdier — and that could be a good thing for the sport
item.description: Fans took over last night's US Open match in New York in a way that is uncommon for tennis. Matthew Futterman from the Athletic spoke to NPR's Ailsa Chang about changes in tennis etiquette.

item.title: Trump again calls for FCC to revoke ABC and NBC licenses
item.description: President Trump lashed out on social media late Sunday against ABC and NBC, putting the nation's top broadcast regulator once more at the center of his culture wars.

item.title: The controversy around Serena Williams' weight loss is more nuanced than you may think
item.description: The tennis legend is back in the news - but not for her prowess on the court. Why the controversy around her weight loss is more nuanced than you think.

item.title: Record-breaking Chinese blockbuster 'Ne Zha 2' Hits U.S. theaters
item.description: NPR's Mary Louise Kelly speaks with Slate senior editor Jenny Zhang about the Chinese animated movie Ne Zha 2, which broke box-office records even before its U.S. re-release.

item.title: A look at Trump's executive orders on bail and flag burning
item.description: President Trump signed a series of orders doubling down on law enforcement in America's cities, just ahead of hosting South Korean President Lee Jae Myung.

item.title: Back-to-back Israeli strikes kill five journalists at Gaza hospital complex
item.description: Israel attacked a Reuters live feed at a Gaza hospital complex, then struck the reporters and first responders covering that strike.

item.title: For Nourished By Time, music is a labor of love — and a life of labor
item.description: NPR's Juana Summers speaks with Marcus Brown, the musician who records as Nourished By Time. His new album takes inspiration from the working class sounds of Baltimore house music.

item.title: Are weighted vests good for bones and muscle? Fact-checking a fitness trend
item.description: One of the latest fitness trends involves adding weight to your exercise routine by wearing a weighted vest. Influencers claim they help burn calories and build strength. But do they work?
